body.p:
Franklin Co April 17th 62
My Dear Sir

I have received your note in relation to the funeral of my esteemed friend Mr Geo Johnson and am very sorry that it finds me in such a condition that is so impossible for me to speak. I got wet some days since in returning from Lexington & have been in consequence suffering with an affection of my throat, to which I am subject, & have been almost unable to make myself understood untill yesterday & there attempting to read for a few moments at a prayer meeting I became so hoarse as to be scarcely able to speak atall. I know that were I to attempt it I should break down & perhaps produce permanent disease of my throat. It will give me a mournful satisfaction to go to the burial if the weather permits, but you will have to get some other speaker
I have been this morning informed that the Pastor of Georgetown Church told a minister a short time since who sympathizes with the South that the Church would not permit him to ask that minister unto his pulpit & I very much fear that you will be denied the use of the house. I hope however for the sake of humanity & and the good name of Christianity that no objection may be made. I will go or send to see Mr George Hewet this evening & get him to attend & I have no doubt he will take pleasure in officiating shd you wish it.

Please say to Mrs Johnson that she has my heartfelt sympathy. I know that no earthly consolation can reach her sorrow & I wd not mock her with this offer. But I trust she has an interest with him who has said he is a husband to the widow.
May God protect her noble boys who are battling for their homes.
It will not do to rely on the uncertainty of George Hunt's acting, especially from the feeling which prevails in his Church averse to it.
I shall immediately write to Dr Rankin to see Mr Mcginn the Pastor of the Reformed Church. I know he will take pleasure in officiating.
